descriptionMarkdown:
Usage
====

You need the Circuit Network tech.

1. Create the base of the mall
1. Add more assembly sections
1. Add more direct supply lines for high volume resources
1. Close the far end belt loops, leaving the outer loop a few belts longer than the inner
1. Configure max counter for each high volume resource
1. Enable supply lines by enabling the corresponding constant combinator. The sushi will now be initialized with basic resources. Check the counter (the green circuits).
1. Configure production in assemblers. Take away the delivery chest if not needed. Configure belt inserter if the product should return to the belt. Both inserters can be used.

Advantages and disadvantages
====
+ Modular, flexible
+ Easy to extend
+ Easy to add new production
+ Independent of mods
+ Input resources can go anywhere

But

- Somewhat complicated to set up. A knowledge of circuits helps.
- A mistake can destroy the count. It can also be hard to track down.

Details
====
There are three ways to input resources.
1. For high volume, use the direct supply lines. High volume intermediary products like gears, copper wires and green circuits are better created outside of the mall and supplied as an external resource (in contrast to buss based systems where these are usually manufactured locally).
1. For low volume manufactured resources, use assembly machines in the mall.
1. You can also directly drop resources into the drain buffer, they will be correctly counted and inserted. 

You can supervise the function in several ways. mouse-over the counter combinator to see the current amount of resources. There is also a group that reads an average number of resources on a sub section of the sushi belt and presents this as a percentage. The percentage should not exceed 70 when resources are evenly scattered.

Be careful not to pick up resources manually from the belt as the counter will be off. Just a few in a hundred doesn't much matter, though.

Configure a new assembly machine
----
1. Set the new recipe, and it will start immediately if there are available resources.
2. Remove the output chest for intermediary products unless you want to save some for yourself.
3. Default is to not put the product back on the sushi belt. To enable this, click on the inserter, set a condition for the produced type and an amount. I usually start at 20.

Configure a direct line input
------
1. Connect an  input resource
1. Set the inserter condition to be active when the resource is below a certain limit. High volume resources, e.g. iron plates, can be set to 100.
1. The resource will immediately be added. Check the counter to make sure it is included.

Extending the mall
====
We want the outer belt to be longer than the inner belt to gradually spread out resources. Avoid using the outmost assembly machine or direct line input!

To add more assembly machines, you may need to first extend the belt loop. Easiest way is to rotate the belt segments in the curve first, which will halt the content. Use the blueprint pattern "Assembly section". The wire has to be connected properly to the nearest inserters. This is easily accomplished if creating the pair of machines where one overlaps on the nearest one as the wires will be attached automatically. However, if that machine was in use, it and its inserters will get overwritten.

Close the loop again.

To add more direct line inputs, use the supply section blueprint and have it overlap the last insert point to make sure the wires are attached correctly.

Reset the counters
==========
1. Disable the constant combinator that controls the direct line inputs.
2. Disable the constant combinator that empties the drain buffer.
3. Wait for all resources to drain into the chests on the side.
4. Wait for all assembly machines to halt.
5. There is a green wire connected from the input to the output of the counter combinator. Remove this wire, and the counters will be reset. There may be a few resources released from direct input line, wait for those to be moved into the buffer.
6. Manually remove items from the buffer chests if needed.
7. Re-attach the green wire from the input to the output of the counter combinator. Now everything is reset and ready to power up again.
8. Enable the constant combinator that releases the side buffer content. Check that these are counted and wait for all to be released.
9. Enable the constant combinator that controls the direct line inputs.

Manually attaching wires
=====
1. All inserters adding mats to the sushi belt shall be connected by green wires. Set the mode to "enable/disable", "Read hand contents" and "pulse mode". Configure the condition for the resource to be enabled when less than the amount that you want on the belt.
2. All inserters taking mats off the sushi belt shall be connected by red wires. The usual operation is "None", "Read hand contents" and pulse mode.
3. All direct line belts adding mats to the sushi should also be connected by green wires. same as the first step.
title: Generic modular mall based on a sushi belt
